awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF:  Linking lakes to the landscape: mechanisms that control terrestrial subsidies to pelagic food webs
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Steven Sadro has been awarded an NSF Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship to implement a research and education program at the University of California, Riverside. He will use comparative and experimental approaches to investigate the extent to which variability in the concentration and composition of terrigenous inputs to lakes affects the transfer of terrestrial carbon into pelagic food webs. Terrestrial ecosystems export a considerable amount of organic matter into lakes, but the degree to which such material supports pelagic food webs is debated, and the environmental controls of such subsidies are poorly understood. In this study, the natural abundance of carbon (13C and ∆14C), nitrogen (15N), and hydrogen (2H) isotopes will be used to determine terrestrial contributions to aquatic food webs. Seasonal and spatial driven variation in the quantity and quality of terrestrial inputs will be used along with experimental manipulations to illustrate mechanisms of control on carbon transfers to pelagic organisms. These studies will be carried out in high-elevation lakes, which have consistent spatiotemporal patterns in dissolved organic matter composition driven by elevation and snowmelt dynamics, making them ideal natural laboratories for ecosystem studies of carbon flow. 

Lakes are natural repositories of terrestrial organic matter. The extent to which this material is decomposed, stored, or biologically cycled within lakes has important implications for energy flow, food web structure, and ultimately, the amount of carbon that is exported or released back into the atmosphere as carbon dioxide. However, evidence that terrestrial carbon is incorporated into aquatic food webs remains controversial. By characterizing the mechanisms that control the flow of terrestrial carbon in aquatic food webs, this research will illustrate linkages between organisms and help refine food web models for aquatic systems. Furthermore, high-elevation ecosystems are sensitive to the effects of climate warming; understanding carbon cycling in these systems, in particular, is a critical first step in predicting how ongoing changes in soil, vegetation, and hydrological dynamics will affect aquatic ecosystems. Dr. Sadro will directly incorporate undergraduates in both field and laboratory aspects of this research. He will assist in developing and leading a university field aquatic ecosystem science course taught at the Sierra Nevada Aquatic Research Laboratory facilities, a UC Reserve located in the eastern Sierra. Dr. Sadro will also contribute to the development of a watershed education curriculum serving under-represented secondary school students within the western Sierra Nevada Woodlake Union High School near Visalia, California.

por.por_cntn:
Terrestrial ecosystems export a considerable amount of material into lakes. Organic matter inputs, in particular, play an important role in structuring aquatic ecosystems. Water clarity, temperature, and mixing dynamics are all affected by the amount of organic matter washed into lakes. If consumed by microbes and other aquatic invertebrates, this material may be an important energetic subsidy to higher consumers in lake food webs.

This study explores the extent to which terrestrial organic matter is incorporated into aquatic food webs and the factors that regulate energy transfer in a set of mountain lakes in the Sierra Nevada, California. Mountain ecosystems are an excellent study system to explore these processes because lake productivity is generally low, but there are large elevation-driven gradients in terrestrial inputs, making them a natural laboratory for ecosystem studies of carbon flow. Furthering our understanding of carbon dynamics in mountain lakes will advance general food web theory and help predict how these sensitive systems may change in response to a warming climate.

Principal investigator Sadro sampled 12 lakes spanning a 2000 meter elevation gradient, from low elevation catchments dominated by forest and shrub cover to alpine catchments where vegetation was sparse and rock cover expansive. Dissolved organic matter in these lakes reflected the underlying landscape patterns. Concentrations were low in high-elevation lakes and increased by over a factor of 40 with decreasing elevation. Likewise, the composition of dissolved organic matter reflected increasingly terrestrial sources with decreasing elevation. The additional organic matter in lower elevation lakes fuels higher rates of microbial respiration, as reflected by carbon dioxide concentrations in lakes that increased to over 600% saturation with decreasing elevation. Taken together, these data suggest increased terrestrial loading of organic matter fuels increased rates of carbon cycling in Sierran lakes. To explore if terrestrial carbon was simply being metabolized by microbes or actually incorporated into the biomass of higher consumers, Sadro sampled benthic and pelagic organisms from all study lakes in combination with soil and terrestrial plants for stable isotope analysis.

The natural abundance of carbon (δ13C and ?14C), nitrogen (δ15N), and hydrogen (δ2H) isotopes were used to explore the extent to which carbon of terrestrial origin was incorporated into aquatic food webs among these lakes. Over 2000 isotope samples were analyzed at the Facility for Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometry in the Environmental Science Department at UC Riverside, representing 500 distinct samples. Approximately 60 samples were analyzed for radiocarbon at the National Ocean Sciences Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (NOSAMS) facility at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute. While analyses of these data are ongoing, there are clear patterns in δ13C, ?14C, and δ2H with elevation for a broad suite of organisms. Although modeling to determine relative contributions of different carbon sources is not yet complete, the carbon signature for many invertebrate consumers becomes increasingly similar to terrestrial sources along a decreasing elevation gradient, suggesting terrestrial organic matter increasingly supports aquatic consumer biomass.

The research associated with this fellowship was closely integrated with an existing National Science Foundation supported Long Term Research in Environmental Biology (LTREB) project. The Sierra LTREB project explores lake and watershed responses to inter-annual variability in climate and atmospheric forcing.
